As the fire died down and the smoke cleared, Montag felt a new sense of purpose stirring within him. Cuộc đời ông đã đầy bài toán và thách thức, nhưng bây giờ, trong bếp ấm của nhà văn cũ, ông có thể thưởng thức cuộc sống cuối cùng một cách yên tĩnh. Faber quay lại và nhìn thấy một tia ánh sáng thoáng qua cánh cửa, làm tia cầu thang trông thật đẹp trong ánh sáng đầu đen của đêm. Ông ta nghĩ về những người bạn cũ, những kỉ niệm đẹp đẽ, và sự hy vọng rằng, dù đời sống con người có thể đầy bất ổn, nhưng tình yêu và sự hiểu biết vẫn có thể tồn tại, còn lại, mãn tính. Faber nghĩ rằng, bất kể điều gì xảy ra, ông ta đã làm được điều tốt đẹp nhất mình có thể làm. Ông ta quay lại đến vị trí cạnh bàn, nhìn lại cuốn sách kìa, và có một nụ cười hạnh phúc, thoát khỏi đau đớn và lo lắng. Cuộc đời ông ta đã đến đến đây, và ông ta sẽ hôn đi với lòng yêu thương và hy vọng.

En este mundo digital, donde la información fluye a un ritmo vertiginoso, los libros tradicionales parecen anachronismos. Sin embargo, para algunos, la experiencia de leer un libro impreso es irremplazable. Es una conexión con el pasado, un viaje a través del tiempo que permite a los lectores sumergirse en mundos inventados o realidades documentadas con una profundidad que las pantallas no pueden igualar. Además, los libros pueden ser un recordatorio tangible de momentos compartidos, firmas autógrafas, y notas en las bordes que añaden un toque personal a la lectura. A pesar de que la tecnología ha revolucionado la manera en que aprendemos y nos comunicamos, el libro impreso continúa siendo un símbolo de la historia, la cultura y la pasión por la lectura.

Montag decidió que, a partir de ahora, empezaría a escuchar, a observar, a preguntarse y, si fuera necesario, a buscar información fuera de lo que el sistema le permitía. Era un inicio delicado, pero un paso firme hacia una nueva verdad personal. La búsqueda de conocimiento era peligrosa en su sociedad, pero Montag estaba dispuesto a correr ese riesgo.

The alley was a narrow slit between towering buildings, a forgotten path that seemed to lead nowhere but deeper into the labyrinth of the city's underbelly. Montag's mind raced, trying to piece together a plan. He couldn't stay here; the Hound would inevitably find him. He needed to move, but where? The thought of Clarisse and the old man, Beatty's twisted face, Faber's voice in his ear, all mingled into a chaotic tapestry of motivation and fear. He had to survive, to carry their messages forward, to defy the oppressive regime that sought to burn away all knowledge and individuality. Slowly, cautiously, Montag began to inch his way along the alley, his eyes scanning for any sign of the Hound or its operators. Each step was a calculated risk, each breath a prayer for silence. The journey ahead was uncertain, fraught with danger, but Montag knew one thing for certain: he could not turn back. The future of a society that had forgotten how to think, to feel, to truly live, rested on his shoulders. And so, with determination etched into every line of his face, Montag continued his flight, a lone figure against the oppressive darkness, a beacon of hope in a world drowning in ignorance.

He turned the handle slowly, feeling the resistance give way as the door creaked open. The interior was shrouded in darkness, but Montag's eyes had adjusted to the night. He stepped inside, closing the door behind him, and began his search for the hidden data drive that could change everything.

The house was dead now, the men gone. He felt its lack of life, the coldness. He was running away from it, but he was not running to anything, he thought, unless it was down and out, on the bottom, where the mud was. He carried the suitcase as a bulging womb, from which, any second, might come machines, tools, another bomb to lob at an unfeeling world. The green glow of the Hound's lantern was a distant radioactivity in his mind. He was running blind, running faster. The edge of the city was only a few blocks away now. He saw the corner, swung wide, and kept going until he was certain he had broken contact with that other world. He slowed, stopped, panting, and looked back. The house was as quiet as it always was. The Hound did not bay. He stood there, feeling the coldness grow until it surrounded him and made him shiver. He felt like a man who had come out of some ancientozark cave. He looked up at the half moon. It was white, thin, a peeled, silver onion. He felt the coldness settle all around him and into him. He began to walk, still carrying the suitcase. He was in the wrong clothes, his display costume, Seashell and Ear thimbles, and in his ears the distant music and talking from the small radios that were everywhere and nowhere, on the air. He was a performer and his audience was gone; he hadn't known the script for this scene, for he had never expected or imagined it. He walked on and on, not looking back. He had gone some distance when he realized that he was not entirely alone. There was another man running along with him in the dark. Montag saw him now, a shape, dimly seen, coming with him in the silence. He felt an irrational gratitude; he wasn't alone. He slowed, the man slowed, they met, and the man said, "Mister, mister, I was coming from the line and I think I recognize you. Aren't you the fireman, the one who..." Montag nodded. "I'm afraid so. Going my way?" "Where do you go when you're running away?" "I'm going to try and find a few misfits like myself." "I'm a retired English professor," said the man. "That's against the law," said Montag. "I know. I haven't burned any books in twenty years, but I tell you, I've started a few fires in my time." "Well, come on then," said Montag. "We'll talk as we walk." They walked on in the raw night.

The woman's calm demeanor, her unflinching acceptance of her imminent death, struck him deeply. He sat there, grappling with the enormity of his discovery, wondering what path he would take next. Would he continue down the road of ignorance, or would he embrace the forbidden knowledge and risk everything to learn more? The decision hung heavily in the air, a pivotal moment that would define the rest of his life. Montag's heart pounded in his chest as he contemplated the future, a future that now seemed both terrifying and infinitely promising.

Lời khai của sách mới đây của tôi, 'The Sieve and the Sand', đề cập đến cảm giác như thế nào khi mất mọi gì mà bạn đã thu thập. Tôi nhớ lại những lúc đó khi tôi cố gắng nhớ lại những câu chuyện từ sách, những hình ảnh, những giấc mơ. Nhưng hầu hết mọi thứ đều rơi đi như than cát qua đĩa. Tôi cảm thấy một sự mất an toàn, một sự thiếu thiện chất. Tôi muốn trở lại và đưa lại điều đó cho người khác, để họ biết giá trị của kiến thức, của truyền thống, và của việc chia sẻ thông tin. Và đó là lý do tôy làm việc mình đang làm. Tôi muốn trở lại và xây dựng lại đám cháy đó, nhằm truyền lại cho những đứa trẻ tương lai."

He shoved the book back into Montag's hands. "Keep this nasty thing away from your wife. Let's get back to our nice, cheerful, whistling fire." He moved toward the door. Montag stood there, the book hidden behind his back, feeling the Hound's electronic eyes on him, and he suddenly thought of the green park and the white city. He thought of the girl's face. He thought of the old man who had whispered, "I know where I'm going." He thought of the old woman who smiled and sat in her burning house. He thought of all these things as he walked toward Beatty, his hand trembling, the book almost falling to the floor. "Captain," he said, in a voice that surprised himself. "I--I want to quit." Beatty looked mildly surprised. "Now that's quite a feat," he said. "Why, I've never seen a fireman want to quit. Great idea! Congratulations! You're a happy man, aren't you?" Beatty's smile was very wide now. "I'm afraid I can't let you do that," Beatty replied, his voice now soft, "I've had too much time and money invested in you, Montag." He paused and then continued, "Every fireman eventually comes to question what he is doing. Every fireman has a moment of doubt. Clarisse McClellan was right when she said our culture is filled with nothing but fun and frolic, and that's why we're in such a mess. But it's the act of questioning itself that's wrong, Montag. We are all cogs in a great machine, each with a specific role to play. Your role is to burn books and ensure the preservation of our society's values. Questioning that leads to chaos and disorder. You've been trained for this, Montag. You've been given the tools to perform your duty. To step away now would be to betray everything you've been taught and everything this society stands for." Beatty's voice grew stern, "Now, hand over the book, and we'll put this little incident behind us. We'll get you back on track, and you'll continue to serve the community as a model fireman." Montag's hand was sweating, his knuckles white as he gripped the book. He could feel the weight of it, the texture of the pages, the words inside yearning to be read, understood, and shared. "I don't want to betray anyone," Montag said, his voice barely above a whisper. "But I can't do this anymore. I can't burn books. I want to learn from them, not destroy them." Beatty's smile vanished, replaced by a look of cold disappointment. "Well, then," he said, "it seems we have no choice." He reached into his coat pocket and tossed Montag a small, black, snakelike object. "It's a mechanical hound. It can track a single individual's chemical, thermal, and seismic trace. It's useless against running water, but other than that, it's close to foolproof. We'll track the book's trace. It'll lead us to its owners, and we'll apprehend them. As for you, Montag, you'll turn in your equipment, your uniform, and your badge. You'll be discharged from the fire department. Consider this a form of early retirement." Beatty turned and walked away, leaving Montag alone with the ticking mechanical hound. Montag's heart pounded in his chest. He knew he had crossed a line from which there was no return. The world he had known was crumbling around him, and he was stepping into the unknown. He had to act quickly. He glanced around the firehouse, noting the locations of the other firemen and the mechanical hound. His mind raced, formulating a plan. He needed to escape, to find others like him who dared to think and question, to find a place where books were cherished, not burned. La verdad, según Beatty, es simple y directa: uno debe confiar en el sistema, en el orden establecido. Los libros son herramientas de desorientación, instrumentos de la confusión que llevan a la gente a cuestionar el status quo. Pero la sociedad, bajo la guía sabia de los incendios y de los que, como él, defienden su legado, ha encontrado su verdadera paz en la uniformidad. La diversidad de opiniones es lo que lleva a la discordia, y la única manera de mantener el orden es erradicar cualquier influencia que proporcione perspectivas alternativas. Por eso, los libros deben quemarse, para mantener la cohesión social y prevenir la caída en el caos. La ley, según Beatty, es un reflejo de la sabiduría colectiva, y aquellos que no pueden ver esto, aquellos que siguen escuchando voces disidentes, están destinados a la eliminación. La razón detrás de la destrucción de libros es, por tanto, una lucha por la supervivencia de un sistema que promete seguridad a través de la uniformidad ideológica. La sensatez común, según su visión, reside en la aceptación de esta verdad irrefutable.

He leaned back in his chair, his eyes scanning the faces before him, a silent challenge hanging in the air. Las decisiones que había tomado, cada movimiento estratégico, ahora parecían ser preguntas sin respuesta. El conflicto en el Océano Atlántico era un duelo silencioso, donde los submarinos eran los verdaderos cazadores. La tensión era palpable, y el peligro constante recordaba a Beatty de que cada movimiento podía ser el último. Debía mantener la moral alta de su flota, pero sabía que cada día traía nuevas pérdidas. La guerra no mostraba signos de aguantar un respiro, y el mar continuaba siendo el escenario de tragedias inesperadas.

en_second_half: and down the walls like confetti or blood or sherry or sauterne. You like baseball, don't you, Montag?”
en_results_raw: completion The theatres, once grand stages for human drama, now echo with the laughter and tears of clowns, their painted smiles and sorrowful gazes reflected infinitely in the glass walls. The rooms, bathed in hues of vibrant purples, soft blues, and cheerful yellows, create an illusion of being both inside and outside, a dreamlike space where reality blurs with fantasy. The floors are carpeted in plush, patterned rugs that muffle the sounds of the performers, turning each step into a silent dance. The air is filled with the scent of popcorn and the faint, distant sound of a melancholic tune played on a calliope, adding to the surreal atmosphere. The clowns move about with exaggerated grace, their actions a blend of slapstick comedy and poignant mime, their reflections in the glass walls multiplying their presence, creating a circus of infinite jesters. The pretty colours run up the walls in a chaotic yet harmonious pattern, suggesting a world where rules are bent and the impossible becomes possible. This is a place where the boundaries between performer and audience dissolve, where every spectator becomes a participant in the grand illusion. The glass walls, while offering a glimpse into this whimsical world, also serve as a barrier, reminding the onlookers of their own reality, a stark contrast to the vibrant chaos within. It is a space that invites wonder and reflection, a testament to the enduring power of the circus to captivate and inspire.

Además, los libros pueden ser un recordatorio tangible de momentos compartidos, firmas autógrafas, y notas en las bordes que añaden un toque personal a la lectura. A pesar de que la tecnología ha revolucionado la manera en que aprendemos y nos comunicamos, el libro impreso continúa siendo un símbolo de la historia, la cultura y la pasión por la lectura.

Trong câu "Đường mà chúng ta chọn là đường đóng băng, và đó là điều đáng gloat", Frost thể hiện sự đoán đoạt về quyết định cá nhân và sự tự hào về việc theo đuổi đường độc lập. Bài thơ không chỉ đặt ra vấn đề về lựa chọn mà còn thể hiện sự nhận thức về thái độ độc lập và sự đoán đoạt trong cuộc sống. Bài thơ đã trở thành một biểu tượng cho việc đấu tranh với cuộc sống và quyết định cá nhân, đặt ra câu hỏi về sự độc lập và sự khác biệt của mỗi người trong quá trình tìm kiếm đường đến tương lai cá nhân.

Una lucha incipiente pero determinada por restaurar el valor de la humanidad, la comprensión mutua y la paz. Aunque la batalla sea difícil y las posibilidades parezcan escasas, la lucha es digna. La resistencia, la educación y el amor por la vida son armas más poderosas que cualquier tecnología destructiva. Montag y sus aliados saben que el futuro no está asegurado, pero están dispuestos a luchar por él, unidos por una causa más grande que sus propios intereses. La sociedad está en un punto de inflexión, y aunque la resistencia sea silenciosa y desesperada, cada acción cuenta. La historia aún puede escribirse de una manera diferente, pero solo si están dispuestos a luchar por ella.

en_results_raw: As the dust settled, the soldiers scrambled to their feet, their faces etched with a mix of confusion and determination. The sudden stop had been unexpected, a jarring contrast to the smooth ride they had been enjoying moments before. The vehicle's engine growled, a low rumble that vibrated through the metal frame, signaling that it was ready for whatever came next. The commander, Captain Hayes, was the first to regain his composure, his gaze sweeping over the rugged terrain that stretched out before them. "Status report," he barked, his voice cutting through the lingering chaos. The crew responded with a series of affirmations and updates, their hands moving swiftly over controls and displays. The Salamander, a heavily armored transport designed for the most treacherous terrains, had been their lifeline through the war-torn lands. Now, it seemed, their journey was about to take an unforeseen turn. The captain's eyes narrowed as he peered through the vehicle's viewport, his mind racing through the possibilities. "Prepare for engagement," he ordered, his tone leaving no room for debate. The Salamander was not just a transport; it was a fortress on wheels, equipped with enough firepower to hold off an entire platoon. The crew sprang into action, their movements precise and practiced. Outside, the landscape offered little in terms of cover, the barren expanse a stark reminder of the harsh conditions they were up against. The enemy could be anywhere, hidden in the shadows or waiting in ambush. Captain Hayes knew that the next few moments would determine the fate of his squad. As the tension mounted, the Salamander's doors sealed shut with a heavy thud, the sound echoing through the interior. The crew braced themselves, ready to face whatever lay ahead. The war had taught them one thing: adapt or perish. And the Salamander, with its crew of battle-hardened veterans, was ready to adapt.

Semenderin nedenleri çeşitli olabilir; deniz suyu akışı, tuzlu topraklar, yağsal malzemelerin dağıtımı ve insan etkileri arasında sayılabilir. Semenderin etkileri, kaymalar, sıçramalar, evlerin ve infrastrukturun bozulması, tarım alanlarının hasar görmesi ve ekonomik kaybı içerebilir. Bu nedenle, semenderin önlenmesi ve yönetilmesi konusunda önleyici çabaları önemlidir. Bu, doğal güvenlik stratejilerinin geliştirilmesi, semenderin tahmini ve izleme sistemleri geliştirilmesi, ve semenderin etkilerini en aza indirmek için hızlı ve etkili müdahale stratejilerinin uygulanması gerekmektedir.

en_results_raw: Montag walked slowly toward the fire and the five old men sitting there dressed in dark blue, their faces illuminated by the flickering flames. The air was thick with the scent of burning, a smell that had once been comforting, now tinged with unease. He could hear the crackling of the fire, a sound that used to fill him with a sense of purpose and belonging. But today, it felt different. Today, as he approached, he felt a heavy weight in his chest, a foreboding that something was about to change irrevocably. The men looked up as he neared, their eyes reflecting the firelight, unreadable in the dim glow. "Montag," one of them called out, his voice gravelly and deep. "You've come to join us?" Montag hesitated, his hand unconsciously reaching for the books hidden beneath his coat. "I've come to understand," he replied, his voice steady but betraying a tremor of uncertainty. "Understand what?" another man asked, leaning forward, his curiosity piqued. "That fire is a tool," Montag began, his words slow and deliberate, "but it can also be a destroyer. And I've come to realize that what we've been destroying... it's more valuable than we've been led to believe." The men exchanged looks, a mix of skepticism and intrigue passing between them. Montag knew he was on the precipice of a profound revelation, one that could alter the course of his life and perhaps the lives of those around him. As he stood there, the fire casting dancing shadows on his face, he felt a surge of determination. It was time to challenge the status quo, to question the norms that had bound him and his society for so long. The future was uncertain, but Montag was ready to face it, armed with the knowledge and courage that the forbidden books had given him.

en_first_half: “Listen,” said Granger, taking his arm, and walking with him, holding aside the bushes to let him pass. “When I was a boy my grandfather died, and he was a sculptor. He was also a very kind man who had a lot of love to give the world, and he helped clean up the slum in our town; and he made toys for us and he did a million things in his lifetime; he was always busy with his hands. And when he died, I suddenly realized I wasn't crying for him at all, but for the things he did. I cried because he would never do them again, he would never carve another piece of wood or help
en_second_half: us raise doves and pigeons in the back yard or play the violin the way he did, or tell us jokes the way he did. He was part of us and when he died, all the actions stopped dead and there was no one to do them just the way he did. He was individual. He was an important man. I've never gotten over his death. Often I think, what wonderful carvings never came to birth because he died. How many jokes are missing from the world, and how many homing pigeons untouched by his hands. He shaped the world. He did things to the world. The world was bankrupted of ten million fine actions the night he passed on.”

Las imágenes capturadas por cámaras de video en cohetes ofrecen una perspectiva única, casi poética, de la violencia militar. Esas imágenes, a menudo retratadas en documentales y reportajes, nos recuerdan no solo la devastación física sino también la complejidad moral de las guerras. La tecnología ha permitido que los espectadores en casa experimentaran una forma de presencia en estos eventos, aunque siempre a través de una pantalla. Además, el uso de drones y cámaras digitales avanzadas ha evolucionado enormemente desde entonces, ofreciendo imágenes de calidad superior y perspectivas que antes eran impensables. Pero, volviendo a las películas de cohetes de los cuales te refieres, no recuerdo una especifica. Podría ser debido a que, aunque impactantes, tales imágenes pueden no ser tan emblemáticas como otras memorias de guerra. Sin embargo, la importancia de capturar esos momentos históricos no se puede subestimar, ya que sirven como recordatorio de los costos humanos y morales de los conflictos armados." Granger terminó su explicación, consciente de que cada palabra podía ser crucial en su intento de ganar la confianza de su interlocutor en una situación tan delicada.

tr_second_half: parmakları toprağa pençelenmiş, hepsi birden kulaklarının patlamasını önlemek için, akıllarını kaybetmemek için bağırarak tutuyorlardı. Montag da onlarla birlikte, yüzlerini paralayıp dudaklarını yırtan ve burunlarını kanatan rüzgârı protesto etmek için bağırıyordu.
tr_results_raw: Adamlar, kendi cihazlarına ve teknolojilerine inanıp, doğanın gücünü ve kendi kuvvetlerinin sınırlarını zorlayarak yaşamaya devam etti. Ancak, zamanla onların çabaları, doğal dünyanın dayanıklılığının sınırlarını zorlu bir şekilde test etti. Doğal afetler, sarsılmaz virüsler ve ekolojik degradasyon, insanların yaşam tarzını ve çevrelerini kritik bir şekilde etkileyerek, onların varoluşunun sürdürülebilirliğine dair endişeleri arttırdı.

en_first_half: Silently, Granger arose, felt his arms, and legs, swearing, swearing incessantly under his breath,
en_second_half: tears dripping from his face. He shuffled down to the river to look upstream.
en_results_raw: He couldn't believe the extent of his injuries. The pain was excruciating, a constant reminder of the ordeal he had just survived. As he tried to stand, his legs wobbled beneath him, threatening to give out at any moment. Granger leaned heavily against the wall, his breaths coming in shallow gasps. He knew he needed to move, to find help, but every movement sent fresh waves of agony coursing through his body. Despite the pain, he pushed himself forward, each step a battle against his own body's betrayal. The night was dark and cold, and the forest around him seemed to close in, as if the very trees were conspiring against him. He swore again, not just at his pain, but at the cruel twist of fate that had led him here. He needed to stay focused, to keep moving, but the darkness and his injuries made it a daunting task. Granger's mind raced, trying to piece together what had happened, how he had ended up in this dire situation. The memories were fragmented, flashes of light, sound, and fear. He couldn't afford to dwell on them now; survival was his only priority. With determination, he continued his slow, painful journey, each step a testament to his will to live. The night seemed endless, but Granger pressed on, driven by an indomitable spirit that refused to be broken.
vi_first_half: Lặng lẽ, Granger ngồi dậy, sờ tay sờ chân, chửi thề, thì thào chửi thề không ngừng,
vi_second_half: nước mắt từ mặt ông nhểu xuống. Ông tập tễnh đi xuống bờ sông nhìn lên thượng nguồn.
vi_results_raw: nhìn lên, thấy mặt trời đang mọc lên từ phía đông. Ông ta nhận ra rằng đây là một ngày mới, một bước tiến mới trong cuộc chiến. Ông Granger đã quyết định, bất kể điều gì cả, ông sẽ phát triển kỹ năng mágic của mình và đưa đoàn tụ họ thành công. Ông biết rằng việc này sẽ không dễ dàng, nhưng ông cũng biết rằng ông có thể giúp đỡ đồng đội của mình bằng cách sử dụng kiến thức và kinh nghiệm của mình.
es_first_half: En silencio, Granger se levantó, se palpó los brazos, las piernas, blasfemando, blasfemando incesantemente entre dientes,
es_second_half: mientras las lágrimas le corrían por el rostro. Se arrastró hacia el río para mirar aguas arriba.
es_results_raw: buscando cualquier señal de vida, cualquier señal de que su cuerpo aún respondía a algo más allá de la muerte que lo envolvía. La oscuridad del pasillo de Hogwarts parecía más oscura que nunca, como si el mundo mismo se hubiera apagado para honrar la tragedia que había sucedido. La pérdida de Sirius Black había dejado una grieta profunda en el corazón de todos los que lo conocían, y a Granger, con su lógica y su determinación, le pesaba particularmente fuerte.
tr_first_half: Sessizce, ellerini ayaklarını kontrol edip küfrederek, dişlerinin arasından küfrederek ve gözlerinden
tr_second_half: yaşlar akarak, Granger ayağa kalktı. Ayaklarını sürüyerek ırmağın akıntısına bakmak için yürüdü.
tr_results_raw: birbirine bakarak, huzursuzluğunu hissediyordu. Gece, karanlıkta, sadece sesin de o anı boyunca duyulduğu. Bir süre sonra, bir ses, uzakta, hafif ve kısa, onu hatırlattı: telefon. Uyanık olmak zorunda kaldı. Telefonu alarak, gözlerini kapanarak yanıt verdi. "Merhaba?" Dişlerini birbirine sıkıca sarıp, sesini düşürdü, mutsuzluğunu gizlemek için. "Ben burada, ne oldu?" Diğer yanında, sessizce odada oturuyor, sadece sesin anlamını aradığı birisiydı. Ancak, telefonun sesi, onun huzursuzluğunu arttırdı. "Evet, ben burada. Her şey iyi?" diye sorar, ancak kalbinin dudaklarından bir ses, gerçek anlamı anlamayacak kadar hassasydı. "Evet, her şey iyi," diye cevap verildi, fakat sesin derinliği ve uzaklığı, onu endişe etti. Gece daha uzun sürdü ve bir süre sonra, uykuyla karşılaştı. Ancak, rüyalarında da sessizliğin ve korkunun sensasyonu devam etti.

en_first_half: “Now, let's get on upstream,” said Granger. “And hold on to one thought: You're not important. You're not anything. Some day the load we're carrying with us may help someone. But even when we had the books on hand, a long time ago, we didn't use what we got out of them. We went right on insulting the dead. We went right on spitting in the graves of all the poor ones who died before us. We're going to meet a lot of lonely people in the next week
en_second_half: and the next month and the next year. And when they ask us what we're doing, you can say, We're remembering. That's where we'll win out in the long run. And some day we'll remember so much that we'll build the biggest goddam steam-shovel in history and dig the biggest grave of all time and shove war in and cover it up. Come on now, we're going to go build a mirror-factory first and put out nothing but mirrors for the next year and take a long look in them.”
en_results_raw: of the passage.

Một ngày nào đó gánh nặng ta mang theo mình có thể giúp cho ai đó. Nhưng ngay cả hồi còn có sách trong tay, đã lâu rồi, chúng ta cũng đâu có dùng những gì thu được từ sách. Chứng ta cứ vậy mà sỉ nhục người đã chết. Chúng ta cứ vậy mà nhổ lên nấm mồ tất cả những người đáng thương chết trước chúng ta. Tuần sau tháng sau năm sau chúng ta sẽ gặp nhiều

Và một ngày nào đó chứng ta sẽ nhớ nhiều đến nỗi chúng ta sẽ làm ra cái máy xúc chạy hơi nước to nhất trong lịch sử, đào nấm mồ to nhất mọi thời đại, hất chiến tranh vào đó rồi lấp lại. es_first_half: —Ahora, vámonos río arriba —dijo George—. Y tengamos presente una cosa: no somos importantes. No somos nada. Algún día, la carga que llevamos con nosotros puede ayudar a alguien. Pero incluso cuando teníamos los libros en la mano, mucho tiempo atrás, no utilizamos lo que sacábamos de ellos. Proseguimos impertérritos insultando a los muertos. Proseguimos escupiendo sobre las tumbas de todos los pobres que habían muerto antes que nosotros. Durante la próxima semana, el próximo mes y el próximo año
es_second_half: vamos a conocer a mucha gente solitaria. Y cuando nos pregunten lo que hacemos, podemos decir: «Estamos recordando.» Ahí es donde venceremos a la larga. Y, algún día, recordaremos tanto, que construiremos la mayor pala mecánica de la Historia, con la que excavaremos la sepultura mayor de todos los tiempos, donde meteremos la guerra y la enterraremos. Vamos, ahora. Ante todo, deberemos construir una fábrica de espejos, y durante el próximo año, sólo fabricaremos espejos y nos miraremos prolongadamente en ellos.
es_results_raw: George se detuvo, observando la naturaleza que los rodeaba. La serenidad del lugar parecía penetrar su alma agitada, llevándola a reflexionar sobre sus palabras. "Entonces, ¿qué es lo que realmente importa?" preguntó él a sí mismo, mientras caminaban hacia arriba, dejando atrás las ruinas de un pasado lleno de errores y arrogancia. "Si no somos importantes, si no somos nada, ¿por qué insistimos en mantenernos atrapados en nuestras propias sombras?"

Bir gün taşıdığımız yük birine yardımcı olabilir. Fakat uzun süre önce, elimizde kitaplar olduğu zaman bile, onlardan çıkardığımız şeyleri kullanmadık. Ölülere sövmeye devam ettik. Bir gün, o kadar çok şey hatırlayacağız ki, tarihin en büyük buharlı kazı makinesini yaparak bütün zamanların en büyük mezarını kazıp, savaşı içine ittikten sonra üstünü örteceğiz.
